Posts.Title: Anyone start rads in October? Motherbeartosix Helenhsm

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 09:16PM jpann39 wrote: Ok, I read back and you all sound like your doing well....your antics here almost (but not quite!!!!) make me wish I were going through my rad treatment with your group....you are all so happy and strong!!!!.....you are very similar to the group of ladies that befriended me here through treatment and as you will find...these friends dont go away once treatment is over....I still visit daily with many of the ladies that traveled my journey with me...some of have moved on to chatting on msn or yahoo and then there is an entire group of us that have a group going on yahoo as well....the friendships you are making here will always be with you...... ok, enough of the insight on life here!!!!! I read back a page or two so hopefully Im not already giving advice that someone else has already given. 4tngupnblu: you said something in one of your posts about bone lose and the dr. saying to up your calcium intake....I didnt have bone lose but was taking Arimidex so thought I should start taking a calcium +D supplement...I was taking 1200 mg per day as recommended and about 3 wks into it I was plagued with twitchy legs at night, so much so that it was keeping me awake....upon further research I found that if you take a calcium supplement you should so increase your magnesium intake as it helps your system obsorb the calcium....just a thought, if you start experiencing odd things you might back off on the dose of calcium (as I did) or add the mag and see what happens..... Penni: You were questioning whether or not to take tamoxifen during rads....I started the tamox in January and started rads in Feb...no one said not to take it during rads and I was a full 3 wks into rads before the nurse finally saw it in my chart and questioned it...she said they dont usually like you to take it during because in some people it can cause the radiation burns to be more severe...since I was already 3 wks into it and didnt have burn issues I took it all the way through....And the male tech thing!!!!! when I first started the tech was a woman, but then as time went on I ended up with two male techs...they were very discrete about things....keeping "both boobs" covered until immediately before zapping and then only exposing the portion the needed...they were very gentle and compasionate about it... Laynel57: Braless, no that is a conversation :)...Im smaller breasted so have always been able to go braless whenever I wanted but out grew those days and have worn one daily for years.....I stopped wearing a bra the first treatment and wore white cotton tank tops under other blouses and found it very comfy...it was kind of strange to be going to work braless though as I work in an office mainly of males..... Helensm: Tattoos-a conversation I will never forget having with my 27 yr old daughter....recently my daughter and her girl friend were over in the evening and we were discussing tattoos....both girls have discreet ones...I said "hey, I have four..." they laughed as they know I dont really have tattoos, so I ended up showing them the four tiny markers....I was teasing and said that the one on my inner/upper part of my breast that shows when I wear low cut tops I was going to have tattooed over with a smiley face....my daughter got the most ghastly look on her face.....she told me that I had just given her WAY too much information.....all I could do was laugh, she didnt think it was funny a week later either when I stopped by her home and walllllaaaaaa theres a  just barely peeking out of my neckline....I had gotten a fake one placed there just to tease her....we are very close, but she said I was pushing my luck .... Sorry my post is so long but you ladies just have WAY too much fun here .....Remember I will be back to check on you so keep up the good work girls.....your almost to the finish line!!!!!!!! (wow, that is almost scarey, I can only imagine the party you ladies will be throwing!!!!!!!) Hugs Jule

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 08:40AM jpann39 wrote: Hi Jas_man Im very sorry you have had to deal with breast cancer but you have found a wonderful site here. My tumor was 2.4 cm with no nodes involved...I had the OncotypeDx test done on my tumor and recieved a score of 12 which put me in the low benefit category for using chemo...I choose no to the chemo and did 37 radiation treatments, hysterectomy due to being er+ 95% and pr+ 55% and am currently taking tamoxiphen....that was 25 months ago and Im doing wonderful....just passed a follow up visit with my oncologist with flying colors. I was 45 at the time of diagnosis's and not as familiar with treatment for someone your age but I have read here that chemo is always in the plan when one is so young but it is doable and you will find lots of support here from many women who have done it....there is also a section for young women on this site that if you havent discovered you might check out. Hugs and best wishes Happy Holidays Jule

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 01:23PM jpann39 wrote: I believe they are beginning to use the Oncotype testing for node positives as well but I think it is only if there are only one or two positive. There are alots of ladies who have had one node positive and chose no chemo. Im assuming since you are taking tamoxifen your stats were er positive so they would feel that anti-hormonals would do better for you than to risk the side effects of chemo for such a small benefit. As Tami says, if your not comfortable requested a second opinion or if you have trust in your oncologist ask him/her for a more detailed reason as to why no chemo. Best wishes Jule

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2008 03:03AM jpann39 wrote: Sugar, Im sorry to so crispy ...I know how miserable it is... My rad nurse gave me these medicated gel pads and fashioned a undershirt type holder thing out of tube gauze for me....but that gel pad thingy, now that worked wonderfully...I healed immedately.. I had one left that I didnt use and I sent it to a lady from here but I didnt write down the name of it to give to people..her screen name here I think was Miss Shappen, you might try a pm message to her to see if she remembers what it was called.... And call you rad nurse aske her about it, I was told they use it with all kinds of radiation burns not just bc so they should know what your asking for...its is expensive though, they were something like $40.00 per pad, but I had insurance that covered them.. The other thing my rad onco prescribed for me was silvedine cream, it is a special cream for burn patients so ask for that instead of the hydrocortizone. Hope this helps.... Jule

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 04:24PM - edited May 5, 2008 04:26PM by jpann39 Apple, Im sorry you are feeling so overwhelmed but what the ladies are all saying is very true.....this will NOT go away.....do you want your children to see you deteriate into a pile of bones like that??? See you suffer? Ive been there, my dad had cancer and he did the exact thing you are talking about doing....DENYING it, he would not go to the doctor even and then by the time he finally did it was too late he was consumed with the ugly, nasty beast and there was nothing anyone could do...I was a full grown adult when this happened...I quit my job and stayed home with him because that is what he wanted....He was blessed to not have suffered like so many do....I lost my dad within 3 wks of him being offically dx'd....I was with him holding his hand when he died....I wouldnt change those last weeks or moment for anything in this world, but let me tell you the anger I felt for a very long time after was almost debilitating!!!!! I was angry at my dad for doing that to me.....I kept praying and asking him WHY, why didn't he seek treatment so that I had him for longer??? Obviously I will never have an answer to that question..... I cant imagine being a young child and going through that....please dont do that to yourself or your children....you will and can get through this!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! let others help, ask you kids to help. I know Im pretty gruff in my statements here and I know your scared silly, we all were/are, but to even consider purposely letting this happen to you and you family is unthinkable....

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 08:20PM jpann39 wrote: I found the lump in the shower, called my primary care doctor, she saw me the very next day, she found the lump on her own without me telling her even which breast it was in....she sent me for mammo & ultra sound two days later on a Monday....the ultra sound tech said that the radiologist would like to talk to me so he came in and said that he thought I should have the lump biopsied...said there are several ways, I asked what he recommended, he said core needle as the lump was at least 2 cm....asked when he could do it, he said now....I said do it...I had the results back in two days... My primary (which I have known for about 10 yrs) waited until after office hours and called me at home to tell me so she could talk with me on a personal level....before telling me she did give me the option to meet her the next day for the results....I choose for her to tell me that night on the phone as I pretty much felt in my heart that it was cancer and I needed the time alone before telling anyone else so that I could absorb it myself.... Im now just over a year out from that call and doing wonderfully....Im not the same person I use to be before hearing that I had breast cancer and find that I still get really really scared right before an appt but I think after time and if all goes well and the cancer stays gone those feelings will ease.... Jule P.S. My primary is also the one who I asked about the surgeon. I asked her which one she would use if she were in my shoes and thats the one I choose....He was a wonderful surgeon
Posts.Title: How were you told basil16883 AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2008 07:57AM jpann39 wrote: samcid, Have you spoken with your oncologist about have the OncotypeDx testing done??? I had a complete hystroectomy at 46 due to my bc being ER95%+.....I did alot of research about this before making my decision and found that mostly highly ER+ woman have their ovaries shut down in some fashion.... My oncologist NEVER recommended chemo to me and my bc was stage 2 w/no nodes involved but high er/pr status... I wasnt certain about my decision to not do chemo so had the above testing done and....they test a sample of your tumor and give it score as to whether chemo would be useful to you or not....I dont remember the exta numbers but my score was 12 which feel in the low range category and said that chemo would hold little benefit for me....I choose to have lumpectomy, rads, hystorectomy and am currently on Tamox with very little side effects.....a week after my hystorectomy they changed me to Arimidex but I switched back after 3 months because of the aches and pains of the Arimidex....my oncologist suggested that I try the AI again in May....which I think I will. Hope this helps you in your decision making... Jule

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 09:18AM jpann39 wrote: I double the "WELL SAID" comment from Mary!!!!!!! The outside world has no idea what all the things we go through trying to fight to survive does to our bodies on a long term effect. And I also agree with the statement that the medical world needs to make the fatigue from treatment more openly known.....yes, they told me rads were gonna kick my hinney, but it seems so easy so I was full steam ahead, then when it did hit I felt like I'd been run over by a truck and still do at close to 2 yrs out....if they know enough to tell you ahead that these treatments (even the simpler ones like rads) are going to do this then I believe they should be more open about it..not just a small warning...maybe if I had known the full version of it I would have backed off and rested more in the beginning so it might have not kicked me so hard at the end... Im in a relationship that is just only 6 months old and he is very understanding but I dont think he fully understands it, as we werent together during my treatment...Im just extremely thankful that he tries to understand it at all. Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2009 12:55PM jpann39 wrote: Molly Im sorry you find yourself here at all but to feel that your doctors are leaving you behind is a bit more than you should be dealing with... Do you have another appt with the surgeon before surgery??? If not you should make one.....get yourself a pen and paper and start writing questions....go in there and sit down with the doctor and address your questions.....I did this with my surgeon because one of my fears was to be brought out of surgery, woke up and told I needed more done and going back to surgery.....I was very clear with him that if he got in there and felt that I would be better with a mastectomy than a lumpectomy I didnt want to be woke, just do it and tell me later..... The thing here is...this is you, your body....they need to discuss everything with you prior to going to surgery. Best wishes Jule

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2008 08:15AM jpann39 wrote: Mary-thank you for the vote of confident on the relationship issue but I think I just got lucky....I really dont have any earth shattering advice for "Finding Love After BC" so not sure that thread would go very far.... Althea-I dont think the medical field takes it seriously enough either....my rad oncologist and his nurse are the ones that talked to me about it, but it was more the nurse than the doc and she was talking to me about it because she says she actually sees it week to week as the patients go through their rad treatment. She was wonderful, it would be nice for every docs office to have a head nurse like Lori. Kerry-I lived alone and worked full time through my bc journey, but for me I think mentally/emotionall I NEEDED to work...I work for the state here so benefits and time off are not an issue (THANKFULLY)...There were days that I had to drag my hinney to work and put on a stiff upper lip to stay once I got there but the thing that always got me going was the thought that once I got home I would be alone and then my mind would wonder to dark places...the night time was MORE THAN enough time for those thoughts, so I pushed through work daily....I often wonder if my attitude might have been a little less tight about working if I had known how severely the fatige was going to hit me once it finally caught up with me, but Oh well, its done and in the past now so I continue to plug along and I really feel that over time (if I slow down when I first begin to feel the burn out coming) I might actually get back to a more normal level. This is such a wonderful thread, I really appreciate you starting it Mary.....hopefully as we each progress through the stages of this journey we can help each other with what we each have learned. Hugs Jule

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 12:45PM jpann39 wrote: Lori You also might want ask and investigate having the Oncotypedx testing done on your tumor....this is a gene test they use to see what benefit chemo may or may not have for you individually. As I read this site though I see lots of ladies with similar dx's to yours with Grade 2 that are opting out of chemo or stating that their oncologist didnt recommend chemo so they moved on to radiation treatments and hormonals... I dont know your age but that also will be a factor in your oncologists reasoning if they recommend chemo. Im sorry that you are here and in these shoes but this site will be alot of help for you.....Let me suggest that you take someone with you to your appt, make a list of questions to ask then have that person write the answers. Or like I did, take a small tape recorder so that you can tape the meeting. Hugs Jule

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 03:49PM jpann39 wrote: Hi ladies, I was 45 with IDC, 2.4 cm, stage II, grade 1, no nodes, clear margins, Lumpectomy, er/pr+, her2-, rads, hysterectomy, tamox, then arimidex, now back to tamoxifen....my onco score was 12....Im doing very well and will hit my 2 yr mark Nov 15th. Even though my oncologist said I was young to have bc as well as having no family history he still didnt recommend chemo for such a low benefit.....he and the adjuvant online program both said that the long term effect of chemo versus' the benefit of possily 4% for me would not be worth it and I was inclined to believe that. Discuss it with our oncology team, you will make the right decision. If you have a hard time then seek a second opinion from another oncologist. Best wishes Jule

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 12:29PM jpann39 wrote: Sumbunny Im sorry you found yourself in this situation....it is not a fun path to walk but it is very doable!!!! It sounds to me like the sugery that is being talked about is basically a lumpectomy with sentinal node biopsy. The lumpectomy is to remove the lump and a margin area around the outside of it and the SNB is where they inject dye and follow it to the first set of nodes it shows up in then test them to see if there is any bad cells in them. They injected the radio active stuff and the blue dye a couple of hours before my surgery while I was still awake but I was medicated with Valum (spelling?) so wasnt as nervous as I normally would have been.... Dont be afraid to tell them right up front that you need something to help with the nerves & worry....this is an extremely stressful time for you and it is important that you get rest while you heal from surgery....I found that the meds dont take everything away but helped me cope with the stress of all the waiting for tests results..that is what seems to be the hardest part of this journey... Let me know if you have further quesitons or if you just need someone to talk to...Im always looking for a new friend. Jule
Posts.Title: toally nervous sumbunny sbmolee

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 04:28PM jpann39 wrote: Sum It does help to try to stay busy, but it seems that something always brings it back to the front of our minds. The waiting seems to be the worse....once you get some results back and know more what you are dealing with it will get a little easier. Try to take things one step at a time...try to take someone with you to appts IF (and only IF) this comes back as breast cancer then you will want to have a pair of ears with you since it will be hard for you to hear and understand anything past the initial words....also write down questions that you might have or take a tape recorder and record the conversations with your doctors if you have to go further with this. The next things Im going to say are ONLY in case this comes back "c".....normally if chemo is in your future it comes first, then radiation if it is needed, then possibly horomone therapy if the bc is er/pr positive.....but the hardest part is like I said...the waiting for test results is AWFUL in the greatest term of the word....I just about drove myself crazy researching and waiting. As far as your mom, thats a hard choice. I didnt tell my mom until after I had the initial biopsy done and it took me a bit to tell her that it was cancer when I got the results but she was my rock through everything. Im the only girl out of 5 kids so she and I are really close....it was one of the hardest things Ive ever had to do but I live in the same town she does and do spend quite a bit of time with her so decided I had better tell her so she had sometime to get use to the idea if things turned out badly. Im really really sorry you are having to go through this, but keep posting here. We will try to help you as much as we can. Jule

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 06:42PM jpann39 wrote: I agree....you need to get another opinion!!!!!! I cant believe a doctor would even make a recommendation at this point......I personally wouldnt be comfortable with a doctor that would suggest something like this without even knowing what the heck is going on... My surgeon is a highly respected surgeon in this area, although not a breast surgeon, and he basically told me the same thing that Otters doctor told her..... The surgeon and I made an agreement that once he got in there if things looked worse than the biopsy made it appear he was to continue with a complete mastectomy, but if things were as the biopsy said and my breast couldnt be deformed dramatically he would only remove the area he needed to... My core needle biopsy was correct and I have nothing more than a very faint scar from surgery.....I told my surgeon that he probably thought I was crazy when I made him promise to not wake me and tell me I had to have a further surgery that he had my permission to do what needed to be done...he said it is really surprising how many woman now ask him to do things that way....I even had to sign documents with strick instructions as to what he had the authority to proceed with... Please do just let this doctor take your breast........please, please seek a second opinion!!!!.. Jule

I was also pre-meno and chose to have a complete hysterectomy and went on Arimidex but the side effects kicked my hinney so went back to tamoxifen as I had no trouble with that...might try one of the AI's again further down the road though. I just had my 2 yr followup Nov. 12th and got a clean bill of health!!!!!!! I really love hearing the words NED!!!! All of you here will soon be at that mile marker too!!!!  The best advice I can give is to research the crap out of everything then look inside yourself and choose the options that you yourself are comfortable with.....make your decisions and go forward...dont look back. Best wishes to you the both of you!!!! Hugs Jule

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 11:39AM jpann39 wrote: This is a wonderful discussion!!!!!!! And Im sure it is going to turn into a very interesting one as well... I also have an auto-immune issue that was discovered approx...6-9 months prior to my 2.4 cm lump rearing its ugly head...(I also agree with AnneW about the fact that you only hear things if there is something going on and that is why it seems more one sided). Although I dont believe having these types of diseases cause cancer I do believe that the particular one that I have aided in my cancer growing rapidly and led to my discovery of the tumor.. A friend of mine recently wrote an article in regards to the disease that both she and I have....she was able to have conference calls with some of the countries research doctors who actually responded via emails as well and gave thier permission for her to quote them. The disease I have is called Pernicious Anemia-it is a B12 defficency....at dx I had to take high doses of injected b12, which is what I believe made the tumor grow large enough for me to find....I stopped taking those shots as it scares the crap out of me now, but so far I have been able to control the deficency with taking a daily pill....my system no longer obsorbs b12 from foods and when the b12 gets too low it causes sever neropathy in my hands. If anyone is interested in the article I mentioned above, let me know and I will post it...there is alot of good information in it. Best wishes Jule

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 11:31AM jpann39 wrote: Annie, I too had that strange calm about me when I was dx'd.....I didnt loose it until my first 3 month follow up AFTER treatment had ended.....I had my first bilateral mammo since being dx'd and the entire situation wasnt handled very well by the medical world....I was getting calls from one doctor then another....they found something in the other breast, no they didnt, yes they did, no they didnt, yes they did....this went on for 2 days and the last call from my rad oncologists off pushed me over the edge... I live 20 minutes away from their office..I told the worker that called that I didnt want to talk to her or anyone else, that I was getting in my car and they had exactly 30 mintues to clear the doctors schedule because SOMEONE was going to give me explanations when I got there.....I hung up, jumped in my car and headed to the office....just before I got there the doctor himself called me on my cell to see where I was...he had me come on into his office and he explained that, Yes, they do see something  in the "good" breast that he thinks might be DCIS but wont know without biopsy.....Crap, thats all they had to say...I could have dealt with that but this back and forth was just too much for me to handle...I think those two weeks were WAY harder to deal with than my original dx....... I think you might be right when you say "maybe its acceptance", I knew the moment I found the lump that I would hear the words "you have breast cancer"......I dont know or understand why or how I knew since Im the first in my family but I did.....I just knew. Please continue to post and to let us support you through your journey....and always believe that there is light at the end of this tunnel...this is just a bump in your road and you will get through it... Hugs Jule

It is possible that the original measurements arent as firm as believed...my docs actually told me that they can only get an estimated guess but to expect a little smaller or a little larger at surgery. Mine started with clinical measurement at 2.0cm but was acutually 2.4cm at surgery...I only had a 2 wk wait between biopsy dx and surgery but was I was still worried that it had actually grown in that short time since I found the lump myself and found it hard to believe that I was that same area of breast daily in the shower and it just suddenly appeared. I had myself believeing that my tumor was extremely rapid growing.... So try to enjoy the positive steps that you take and not go to the other side of things..... "ITS SHRINKING, ITS SHRINKING YA!!!!!!!!!!!"
Posts.Title: It's Shrinking!! susan13 mommy3abm

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 10:50AM jpann39 wrote: I was pre-meno and 46....I had a complete hysterectomy because my tumor was highly er/pr+.... My docs never mentioned it to me either...I discovered the info on the internet and didnt even ask them...I told my onco that I was doing it so to please call and make the arrangements....when I met with my gyn/obn about it he said I was making a good choice due to the er/pr+ being so high....also once surgery was over he said that my ovaries were covered in b-9 cyst and he felt sure I would have been looking at issues further down the line. but anyway....I passed my 1 yr this past April of my hyster and feel great...Im also taking tamox as the arimidex made me feel a hundred years old... When I started my bc journey 18 months ago and asked about the ovary removal my onco said it was more common in Europe and isnt or wasnt par for standard care here yet.... If I were both of you I would approach it not as a question but a request if it is really something you want done, but be sure to investigate the se's that come along with it.. Jule
Posts.Title: Drs suggests Ovaries to be removed jdg1 karen1956

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 09:58AM jpann39 wrote: muttnut I also asked this very question of my surgeon, the way he explained it to me is: The first SNB I had they removed 4 (all neg), I had 10 more removed when they found what they thought was a swollen node in my arm pit after radiation treatments ended (it turned out to be a stitch from the original surgery that hadnt disolved) all those were neg as well. The lead node picks up the dye (sentinal), but there are others that potentiall lead to different pathways so they also will pick up the dye...he said that they remove any and all that show dye color as there can be more than just one sentinal.....he explained that it doesnt mean they are infected, which is obviously true as in my case...there are many many women here who have had more than one removed to have the very same results... I will keep you in my thoughts that yours will be the same. Hugs Jule

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2008 02:50PM jpann39 wrote: What a wonderful idea for a thread!!!!! Im not a stage IV but can I join???? I love to crochet frilly doilies, read, fish, camp, snow board, riding 4-wheelers and LOVE my rose gardens!!!!! The strangest thing I do is called GEO Caching-a couple of summers ago my youngest brother and his son were riding their 4-wheelers in a field down the road from their house and decided to look at this really old cemetery (LuAnn-you might have to come Ghost Bust it for them)...while wondering through my brother noticed a pretty new looking ammo box under the tall grass/weeds...they contemplated opening-not opening it, but decided it looked too new to be someones remains.....inside they found all kinds of little trinkets and a small note pad....there were notes and dates from people who had found the stash and traded one trinket for another....It also had a web site address to post your findings and to look for other stashes in your area.........so my (then 12) old nephew and I started Geo Caching.....We found one that had a "travel bug" (kind of a dog tag looking thing w/a number on it) so we looked up the number on the site and discovered that the bug had originally started out on the East coast not to far from New York and its goal was to make it from the East Coast to the West and back home again....I moved the bug 280 miles further on its was towards the west coast earlier this year...the last time I tracked it, it had made its way to the West coast and was last seen on its way back East and was in Montana..... Well, hope everyone has a wonderful thanksgiving!!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 11:04AM jpann39 wrote: I had something similar to this in my arm pit after having my lumpectomy & SNB.....I was 2 wks away from being done with radiation treatments and while showering discovered a lump in my arm pit. At first they told me that it was radiation caused but they were watching it.....I finished rads and they said to wait a bit to see if it would go away....within 3 weeks it hadnt changed so my rad oncologist ordered a biopsy which landed me in the hospital for the day as the lump was too deep for them to biopsy in their office.....it turned out to be an internal stitch from the original snb that didnt dissolve, scar tissue had built around it, they said that the healing from rads probably pronouned the scar tissue and thats why it got large. Hopefully yours is something silly like this too!!!!!! Oh and I was I think about 2 3 months out of the original lumpectomy surgery. Best wishes Jule

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 02:49PM jpann39 wrote: Ulla, I dont remember but I had that error on my computer at home too.....I think I booted the computer into Safe Mode and ran it from there, which is a good idea anyway...... If you dont know how to boot to safe mode, all you have to do it do a restart from your shutdown screen....as soon as the screen goes black start tapping on the F8 key on the top row of your keyboard....that will bring you to a screen that has a listing for different things......#1 is normally safe mode and generally already highlighted, but if not, use the arrow keys on your keyboard to put the highlight on Safe mode and press enter.... This will bring you to destop screen like normal but the icons will be larger, a few missing and such, then a screen will come up and you need to click yes on it.......once you click that screen run the scanner..... Jule PS. I will post the link to the registry cleaner when I get home in awhile.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2009 10:40AM jpann39 wrote: Just weighing in with my experiences in the treatment/no treatment conversation.....most of my dads family has passed with some form or other of cancer and when it was his turn he wouldnt even go to the doctor.....when we finally got him to go because he was in so much pain the cancer had spread most everywhere......they wanted him to have tons of tests ran but he refused....I stopped to see him after work at the hospital one day and he was dressed...I was shocked....I asked if they released him and he said no, but he was going home with me anyway.....I loaded him up and took him home to mom.....his last wish was to spend his favorite holiday at home with those he loved.....July 4th was his favorite...I brought him home June 29th and he passed on July 7th so he got his wish......they gave us tons of meds to keep him comfortable and thankfully they worked....... At first I was angry at him for not seeking medical attention when he first started feeling crappy, but as time as gone by I realized that he had watched and taken care of multiple family members who went through treatment and he made HIS choice to spend the time we had together with quality instead of being ill from treatments that werent going to change the outcome to begin with.... Its a very individual choice and no matter how hard it is I will ALWAYS support someones decision to do or not do treatment.... For myself when the time comes to choose Im not really sure what I will do but I do know that I under no terms want to be a burden on my family or for them to have the memories of suffering... Im sorry I dont post much then come into your conversation and write a huge post but I do read each day and keep all of you in my thoughts... Hugs Jule

Posts.Content: May 26, 2009 07:24PM jpann39 wrote: Ok ladies here's the scoop as I know it right now... David volunteerily went to ER Friday evening....when he got home from work things had progressed to a really nasty state!!!! We got in there and they called a orthopedic specialist in because they thought the infection was in the bone and tendon of his finger....nope not there thankfully....they did a culture and started him on iv meds every 6 hours (so if this makes no sense, Im sorry, I really tired) we did the 6 hour, around the clock thing until this morning...the culture came back yesterday and he has mrsa in a rarer form..they said about 1 in every 10,000 cases...this one is a doooooozy!!!!! it does well with a med for a day or two they gets resistant to it...this morning the changed meds and are putting in a pick line tonight at 7...this med is an every 12 hr so not quite such a pain in the tushy. Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 11:05AM jpann39 wrote: I think I would hold the 7-10 days in front of my mind....if they saw something that needed immediate attention I think they would be having you come in within a few days. I found my lump, had mammo, that lead me straight to ultra sound, that lead straight to radiologist doing immediate core needle biopsy right then and there....I had the results of the biospy in 3 days...
